title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: the Dnmt3aR878H mutation causes metabolic reprogramming in HSPCs, resulting in upregulation of OXPHOS
outcome: Together, these findings indicate that the Dnmt3aR878H mutation causes metabolic reprogramming in HSPCs, resulting in upregulation of OXPHOS.

title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: To test this
context: We postulated that the increased mitochondrial respiration in Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs is required for their competitive advantage over wild-type cells
outcome: we first established an in vitro competition assay in which CD45.2+ Dnmt3aR878H/+ and CD45.1+ Dnmt3a+/+ LK cells were mixed at a ratio of approximately 2:3 and cultured in cytokine-supplemented methylcellulose medium for around 10 days

title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: the proportion of CD45.2+ Dnmt3aR878H/+ cells was consistently 20% to 30% higher than that of CD45.2+ Dnmt3a+/+ cells in the first passage and 40% to 50% higher in the second passage (Extended Data Fig. 1e)
outcome: demonstrating the competitive advantage of the mutant cells

title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: Using this assay, we studied the effect of genetic knockdown of mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) subunits on the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H/+ HSPCs
outcome: by transducing the mixed CD45.2+ mutant–CD45.1+ wild-type population with lentiviral vectors expressing short hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) targeting Ndufv1 and Cox15 (Extended Data Fig. 2a), which encode critical subunits in complex I and complex IV of the ETC, respectively

title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: Downregulation of these genes reduced the basal OCR and competitive advantage of CD45.2+ Dnmt3aR878H/+ cells (Fig. 1d,e)
outcome: indicating that mutant HSPCs are dependent on increased OXPHOS to outcompete their wild-type counterparts

title: Metformin reduces the competitive advantage of Dnmt3aR878H HSPCs
main_content: 4 out of the 8 up-regulated metabolites (l-cysteate, dimethylglycine, reduced glutathione (GSH) and taurine) are involved in one-carbon (1C) metabolism through the methionine cycle (Fig. 3a,b)
outcome: Since the methionine cycle generates SAM, these findings suggest that metformin could potentially affect SAM levels and the ratio of SAM to SAH, which is also known as the methylation index, an indicator of cellular methylation potential
